BUKIT HO SWEE FIRE


2.31 p.m.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Tan Kia Gan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's recommendation to proceed with the motion* standing in my name.


    *The motion reads as follows:

    That this House expresses its profound sympathy for the victims of the fire at Bukit Ho Swee and calls upon the people to donate generously to the Bukit Ho Swee Fire Relief Fund;

    That to prevent a recurrence of such disastrous fires the site of the fire be acquired by the Government for the Housing and Development Board for rebuilding, and to this end that no one be allowed to rebuild on this site structures of a temporary or permanent nature;

    That compensation to private owners for the land to be acquired should be at the value of the land in its encumbered state just before the fire, and that legislation to this end be passed;

    That the Housing and Development Board regulations relating to the prohibition of sub-letting or sharing of accomodation be relaxed in the case of these fire victims in order that rapid re-housing will be possible;

    That this House thanks the fire fighting services, the Police and Military Forces for their work in combating the fire and maintaining order on that occasion and thanks the workers in the Government Social Services and the Voluntary organisations who have helped in the relief of the fire victims.


    The Bukit Ho Swee fire took place on the afternoon of the 25th May, 1961. It was without doubt the worst that Singapore has ever experienced since the war. It devastated an area of some 100 acres and rendered homeless, according to the latest count, a total of 2,833 families - comprising some 15,694 persons, most of whom lost practically all their possessions. Hon. Members of the House have read in the Press of the immediate measures which have been taken by the Government to provide interim relief for the fire victims. They are now housed

Column: 1566

temporarily in five school buildings in the Kim Seng Road area, where voluntary workers, the Government Social Welfare Service, the Army and the Work Brigade have done all they can to relieve the sufferings of the victims and have provided them with food, clothing and blankets.

    The Government has also set up the Bukit Ho Swee Fire Relief Committee under the chairmanship of the Minister for Labour and Law. Representatives from political parties, the Trades Union Congress, student bodies of Universities, the Polytechnic, the Chambers of Commerce, the Council of Social Services, rural and other organisations are serving in this Committee.

    Sir, lessons must be learned from the cause of this fire, and this lesson should strike home with full impact. For the third time since the war, Singapore has bitterly experienced disaster caused by fire. In 1958 the Kampong Koo Chye fire rendered 379 families with 2,050 persons homeless; in 1959 there was the Tiong Bahru fire which affected 1,016 families, comprising 5,200 people; and now the most tragic of them all, the Bukit Ho Swee fire which destroyed the homes of 2,833 families, involving nearly 15,694 people. The common feature about these fires is that they occur in already packed and unauthorised structures of wood and attap. The occupants in all these cases had, in fact, been living in veritable fire traps. If only one house catches fire, then within minutes a blazing inferno would engulf a whole community before the fire fighters could arrive.

Column: 1567



    The unstinted devotion to duty during the disaster of the fire fighting services, the Police and the Military was something to be proud of, but unfortunately They were to a considerable extent hindered by curious crowds who arrived on the scene while the fire was raging and almost choked up the roads, thus delaying the arrival of the fire engines. It is hoped that our citizens would be more civic-minded in future and make an effort to subdue their curiosity and stay away from calamities of this nature which are not really spectacles for enjoyment. I am happy to say that, on the other hand, the fire victims themselves behaved in an exemplary manner and showed no panic. Though the fire took four lives, it would surely have been more disastrous if the crowds of sightseers and spectators had gone out of control and panic had resulted.

    Let us not ignore the lessons of this catastrophe. The reasons for the existence of building by-laws, the need to enforce minimum building standards, and the basic requirements of proper planning should now be painfully clear. We must not be blind to such lessons. We should now understand why the Chief Building Surveyor's Department of my Ministry conducts its campaign against unauthorised structures, which are built in exactly similar conditions to the houses that went up so quickly in flames at Bukit Ho Swee on 25th May. Most of these unauthorised structures are put up by unscrupulous racketeers who live off the miseries of the poor. It is appreciated that the poor people are forced by circumstances to live in these huts because of the acute shortage of cheap housing in the State and that it will be some time before the building programmes of the Housing and Development Board can catch up with this shortage. But I should like to appeal to these people not to fall into the clutches of the racketeers who put up unauthorised buildings for rent or sale. They should never buy or rent any of these structures. They may not only be cheated, but may also become victims of fire.

Column: 1568



    Any building to be put up should be duly authorised by the Building Surveyor's Department. The procedure for the grant of permits for temporary buildings has now been streamlined, and applications should now be dealt with more expeditiously. Government is firmly resolved to discourage the erection of wooden buildings with attap roofs, and in the congested city area to prohibit it altogether. Firm orders have been given to the Chief Building Surveyor to pull down any unauthorised structures as soon as they are spotted.

    The Government will not be discharging its responsibilities to the people if it did not clamp down on unauthorised buildings.

    Sir, it was indeed fortunate that the Bukit Ho Swee fire was brought under control and did not spread further. If circumstances had been adverse the fire could easily have gone out of control with much more disastrous consequences. A conflagration of this magnitude can easily engulf not only attap buildings, but also brick and concrete structures as well. Many brick and concrete buildings were, in fact, destroyed on 25th May, along Havelock Road. If attap and wooden structures were allowed to multiply in the city areas, the next fire might well destroy a considerable section of the city, with considerable loss of lives. I appeal to members of the public to report immediately to the Chief Building Surveyor's Department should they see any unauthorised attap and wooden structures being put up. At the moment, there is a large number of outstanding mandatory orders against unauthorised buildings. Many of these orders require alterations to the unauthorised structures before they can be regularised. Most of the houses, however, cannot be regularised, because they are likely to become dangerous fire traps. There has been a great deal of misunderstanding about the work of the Building Surveyor's Department, particularly when it takes action to demolish unauthorised buildings. But may I repeat that one of the main reasons for this unpleasant action is to save people from the dangers of fire traps, like those of Bukit Ho Swee?

Column: 1569



    This Government will take firm measures to prevent the site of the Bukit Ho Swee fire from being reoccupied by unauthorised structures. The site is to be acquired for re-development by the Housing and Development Board. No doubt, hon. Members will support this proposal as well as the Bill that will be introduced to acquire the land. The project is one designed for the public good and the private owners concerned can be expected not to make a profit out of this disaster.

    Sir, the relief, re-housing and rehabilitation of the fire victims cannot be an easy matter when so many persons are involved. There are not sufficient numbers of vacant Housing and Development Board flats immediately available to re-house every family. Though the public and various Governments have been most generous with their gifts and donations in cash and kind, whatever relief that the fire victims can receive will only provide temporary rehabilitation until they can definitely find their own feet again.

    The Government has decided that all available housing units of the Housing Board should be made available for rehousing the fire victims. In this connection, I should like to appeal to those members of the public who have been on the waiting list for Housing Board accommodation to make a certain amount of sacrifice. There are some 13,000 applicants on the housing register and many of them have been waiting for three, four, or even five years. Just when their chances of being allocated accommodation have improved with the completion of more than 1,000 houses, they have to be told again that the fire victims will be given priority. The Government hopes that these applicants will not grudge the fire victims the special priority given to them. These applicants at least have some form of accommodation at present, while the fire victims have lost both homes and most of their possessions. The Housing and Development

Column: 1570

Board will be building more units soon, and the turn of the applicants who will be given accommodation will not be far off.

    Sir, the following housing units that are immediately available will be set aside for the re-housing of the fire victims:-

    600 flats at Queenstown

    100 flats at Clarence Lane, Alexandra

    300 flats at Tiong Bahru Fire Site

    150 flats at Kallang Estate.

In a few days time the Housing Board will have a further 450 units available at the Tiong Bahru Fire Site, and these too will be allotted to fire victims. Within the next three months, 904 units of one-room $20 flats will be ready at the Tiong Bahru Cemetery Site, and 804 units of two-room flats will be completed at MacPherson Estate, while a further 1,448 units of two-and three-room flats will be ready in Queenstown.

    These flats will be offered to the fire victims at the rents normally charged to members of the public. It is not the intention to upset the very complex rent structure of the Housing and Development Board by introducing rent-free periods or by waiving rents. The Government, while doing all that is right and proper for the fire victims, must not lose sight of the necessity to account to the people for the expenditure of public funds entrusted to its charge. It is considered, therefore, that fire victims should pay the normal rentals charged for the accommodation offered. To assist fire victims further, it is proposed that the Housing Board regulations prohibiting the sub-letting of rooms in flats or the sharing of flats by more than one family be relaxed. The Housing and Development Board does not normally permit its tenants to sub-let any part of their flats, but in order that re-housing of fire victims can be accomplished expeditiously, the Board will be asked to permit fire victims to share accommodation with their friends or relatives now residing in any of the Board's estates. The Board will also accept two

Column: 1571

small families of fire victims joining together to apply for a flat. The Government intends that the relief to fire victims should take the form of equitable distributions in cash and kind so that the amounts of relief to be distributed to the fire victims will be entirely dependent upon the generosity of the people of Singapore and elsewhere. The distribution will be on a per capita and per family basis and it is felt that this method will be the most equitable.

    All fire victim families will receive (a) a rent assistance grant of $7 per person up to a maximum of $35 per family. This sum will, in effect, operate as a rent subsidy, and will be paid for a period of three months; (b) a lump sum rehabilitation grant will be paid to these families; the sum to be paid will be dependent on the monies available in the relief fund after meeting other commitments.

    All families will receive these two grants, whether they accept Housing Board accommodation or not; those not requiring Housing Board accommodation may use their rent assistance grant for finding their own accommodation.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I should like now to thank the public of Singapore, especially those from all walks of life who have donated in cash and kind to the fire victims. The Government respects and admires the concern they have shown for their fellowmen in their hour of need. I should like also to take this opportunity to say how grateful we are to the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya for the personal visit he made to the scene of the fire and for the promise of financial aid from his Government. I also wish to express the Government's appreciation of the prompt and generous donation from the U.K. and U.S. Governments. The relief fund which the Government has set up with the initial contribution of $250,000 will, I expect, continue to grow with more and more donations.

    In conclusion, let me convey to the State and Army Fire fighting services, the Police Force, the Army, and the

Column: 1572

untiring workers in both the Government social services and the voluntary organisations the heartfelt gratitude of the Government for their devotion to the service of those affected by the disaster and for their selfless efforts in their respective spheres-in combating the fire, in maintaining order and in giving much assistance and much appreciated relief to the fire victims.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    Mr Speaker: Before I propose the Question, the Prime Minister has tabled copies of the Bill he proposes to introduce under item 2, and I think hon. Members should have copies of the Bill with them as soon as possible. I therefore propose that these copies be distributed immediately.

    Typed copies of the Bill distributed to hon. Members.

    Mr Speaker: I have had an opportunity of glancing rapidly through the Bill, and it seems to me that the subject matter covered by the Bill is the same as the subject matter of paragraph 3 of the motion. Perhaps the Prime Minister would like to confirm that before I proceed.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, that is so. In fact, it spells out the intention which is contained in paragraph 3 of the motion.

    Mr Speaker: Perhaps it would be convenient for hon. Members if the motion should be posed to the House without paragraph 3, so that there will not be a repetition of the debate on the subject matter of paragraph 3. The debate could take place when we come to the Bill. If that is convenient to hon. Members, I suggest that that would be a better way of doing things.

    The Prime Minister: As you propose, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: I will propose the Question without paragraph 3.

    Question proposed,

    "That this House expresses its profound sympathy for the victims of the fire at Bukit Ho Swee and calls upon the people to donate generously to the Bukit Ho Swee Fire Relief Fund;

Column: 1573



    That to prevent a recurrence of such disastrous fires the site of the fire be acquired by the Government for the Housing and Development Board for rebuilding, and to this end that no one be allowed to rebuild on this site structures of a temporary or permanent nature;

    That the Housing and Development Board regulations relating to the prohibition of sub-letting or sharing of accommodation be relaxed in the case of these fire victims in order that rapid re-housing will be possible;

    That this House thanks the fire fighting services, the Police and Military Forces for their work in combating the fire and maintaining order on that occasion and thanks the workers in the Government Social Services and the voluntary organisations who have helped in the relief of the fire victims."

2.56 p.m.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan (Hong Lim): Mr Speaker, Sir, all of us are in sympathy with and express our grief for the 16,000 people who have been affected by this great fire. From what we know, this is the greatest fire in the history of Singapore. It has brought much misery and ruin in its wake. Sir, on an occasion like this, all of us in this House will forget and sink all political differences which we may have so that everyone may contribute his best to work out a solution for the rehabilitation of our unfortunate brothers and sisters.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I must compliment the Government on all the efforts they have put in on such an occasion. This has been a disaster of magnitude and the Government has, in my opinion, done its best. Tribute must also be paid to all the organisations, both Government and private, which have come to the forefront to rescue and give assistance to the fire victims.

    However, since we have such a motion, I wish to bring forward a few points to the attention of Government. Sir, these should not be taken as criticisms but rather as suggestions for Government to consider. From what I gather, most of the fire victims have one big common problem, that is, when are they going to settle down and start life again? For this, they have to depend so much on Government as well as on other

Column: 1574

persons who have come forward courageously and generously to the assistance of the fire victims. The main problem they are worried about is housing. We are happy to learn from the speech of the Minister for National Development that all efforts will be made to re-house the fire victims. But it has been said that it is not possible to re-house all the fire victims at one time. It is fortunate that there are so many vacant flats to re-house a big portion of the fire victims. But I think Government should consider ways and means of resettling the other victims, either by the erection of temporary structures controlled by Government, or by the use of vacant Government bungalows, of which I think there are still quite a few left, or by the deployment of other vacant buildings in the island. Unless the fire victims are resettled, Sir, those who are employed may not be able to go to work, because they have to look after their children in the fire relief centres. It is what we say a double loss. If they are able to be resettled earlier, those who have employment could go back to their work as soon as possible to earn a few extra dollars to help their families.

    Just now the Minister for National Development has mentioned the question of rent and the question of a free rental period. Sir, the second problem which the fire victims are worried about is the question whether they can afford the rentals and whether the flats allocated to them could be near their place of work. It is not possible to allocate flats to them near their place of work, because there are not many flats being constructed or being completed at the moment near the fire site. I think this is a problem no government can solve. But on the question of rentals, Mr Speaker, Sir, from what I know, most of the houses at present completed, or almost completed, were built at the time when construction costs were the lowest in the last five to 10 years. If we go according to the normal practice of the Housing and Development Board, the rentals charged on these flats should be lower than usual. They are flats which

Column: 1575

were built during the time of the Korean War, when the cost of construction was much more, and persons who are now staying in those houses are bearing the full heavy construction costs because of the increase in prices due to the war. If such a practice is accepted, Mr Speaker, Sir, then these houses should be rented out at what they cost the Housing and Development Board to build, and not on a so-called rational basis where everything is being brought into the pool and distribution of rental is being accepted as a basis.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, just now the Minister for National Development has also touched on the question of three months' free rental and has suggested an alternative of a rent subsidy allowance of $7 per person, up to a maximum of $35 per family. I think, Sir, this is quite a good scheme because normally, during a fire disaster, there are some persons who go back and who get S.I.T. accommodation, and there are others who receive private accommodation, and it will not be fair to those receiving private accommodation if Government offers a three-month free rental to those who are obtaining S.I.T. accommodation. However, in my opinion, the rent subsidy proposed by the Minister just now is below what was offered to the fire victims of the Upper Chin Chew Street fire, or even much lower compared to that offered in the case of the Lorong 3 fire, where each fire victim was given three months' free rental, water and electricity, plus facilities to pay their deposits on an instalment basis if the need arose. I propose that the Government should find out whether there is a way out to increase the rent subsidies proposed to the fire victims, to raise it to a standard which was accepted in the past.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, another problem which the fire victims are worried about is their jobs. Many of them have lost their jobs due to the fire - those persons who have been working on the fire site or those persons whose factories, shops or means of livelihood by hawking and labouring have been destroyed by the fire. I think the Government must give

Column: 1576

consideration to these persons who are unemployed due to the fire, because they have not only lost their belongings and properties, but they also have lost their means of livelihood. A few shops were also affected by the fire, Sir, and it is suggested that, when the Housing Board build new shops around the area, priority be given to those shopkeepers who had shops on the old fire site and preferably these shops should be rented out at lower rentals than usual. Usually the shops are rented out on a tender basis, and the person who bids the highest gets the shop. It has also been suggested. Mr Speaker, Sir, that some of these shops could perhaps be sold to the shopkeepers on an instalment basis.

    Attention perhaps should also be brought to the Government on the organisation at present in the relief centres. First of all, it must be pointed out that none of the Government departments has been prepared or could ever have foreseen a task of such magnitude. But perhaps members of the Government staff will pay attention to some of the complaints or little irritations which may be very trivial to us but which are causing quite a problem to the fire victims. Food is one of the main problems which they are complaining of, Mr Speaker, Sir, It has been pointed out that it now takes about one or two hours to queue up for food, often under the hot sun, and sometimes the persons at the end of the queue do not get vegetables when the supply is finished, and some do not even get rice. This is perhaps because of the bad system of distribution and not because not enough food is being cooked. It has been suggested that if Government would distribute food cards to heads of families instead of every person having to queue up for his food, then it might mean shorter queues and it would mean also a better distribution of food for the fire victims. Mr Speaker, Sir, in one centre, where I think there are nealy 2,000 to 3,000 inmates, there was only one queue and some of them took about three hours to get their food. In such centres perhaps we could establish

Column: 1577

three or four queues. Perhaps the Government has a problem in trying to get the utensils and the necessary equipment, but I think it will not cost very much to buy them.

    Another complaint has been about the cooking of food. It has been said that the rice and vegetables are not properly washed. Yesterday, in one relief centre - I do not know how far this is true - a few persons told us that they found a snake in the vegetables! The rice is of poor quality and quite smelly - perhaps due to lack of washing. I think the question of food can be looked into and improvements made.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is also felt that there is a shortage of doctors and that they are visiting the fire relief centres at periods and not all the time. There have also been complaints of no proper diagnosis of the patients and that many of the patients, especially children, do not get proper treatment. We know this is a drain- on the Government resources of medical staff in the hospitals, but I am putting up this proposal to see whether the Government can try to get supplementary staff either from the Government or from private sources during the next few days to help the victims in the relief centres.

    Many of the fire victims at night have to sleep with their blankets on in the playing fields, because there is no accommodation in the schools. In the last two days, when there was rain, they found it a problem to get even a place to squat down during the night. Perhaps if a few more tents are erected, the problem can be partially solved. The Government has been doing wonderful work in the past few days erecting more tents, but those have been found to be not sufficient. I wonder whether there are ways and means of getting more tents or marquees for sleeping purposes for the fire victims.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it has been proposed that the Ministry of Home Affairs send a special unit to the fire victim centres to help the fire victims get extracts of their

Column: 1578

lost birth certificates and citizenship certificates and other types of certificates. Perhaps on this occasion fees can either be reduced or waived. If much of the red-tape can be cut for the fire victims particularly in applying for these birth certificates and citizenship certificates, I think they would be very grateful to the Government. The Government has already set up an identity card centre in the fire relief centre, and this is a most welcome act.

    Another suggestion is whether Government can send vans to tour the residential areas, particularly the more well-to-do residential areas, during evenings or week-ends to collect blankets, clothing, furniture and cooking utensils which the people might like to donate generously since they have no means of delivering their gifts in kind. Most of these donations in kind and even in cash should, in my opinion, be distributed to the fire victims immediately. It should not take a week or two weeks before they are distributed, because it is at this time that those gifts are most needed, particularly cash or clothing. Some clothing has been distributed, but it is found insufficient.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to repeat that the Government has done whatever it can to relieve the fire victims, arid its work deserves the compliments of all Members of this House.

3.16 p.m.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker. Sir, as a representative of Delta constituency which suffered from the fire, I must fully support the Government's motion in regard to the fire victims.

    Since the Bukit Ho Swee fire disaster, the Government has immediately launched effective relief measures and after-care welfare so that the 10,000 fire victims could be resettled and looked after. Another relief measure of Government is to let the fire victims rebuild their homes so that those people who have long suffered in the past, particularly the Bukit Ho Swee fire victims, can live under better and more favourable conditions in future. This clearly shows that

Column: 1579

the Government which comes from the people is doing its best for the people - to improve the living conditions of the people.

    Since the fire broke out, the Prime Minister, Ministers and all Assemblymen and Assemblywomen have been working very hard. When the fire broke out, the Prime Minister and many Ministers and Assemblymen rushed to the scene to help the people salvage their belongings and to assist the firemen to evacuate the old and young from the site. They have also been consoling the victims day and night and seeing that all helpers and workers do their work properly in accommodating the victims in the various centres.

    As this disaster is the most serious one in the history of Singapore, the fire relief work must be fully supported by all the people of Singapore and support for Government's measures must be given to enable the Government to achieve better results in rebuilding the homes of the victims in a short space of time. At this crucial time, everyone is expressing his good intentions. The people of Singapore have responded to Government's appeal and, have donated generously. This has helped to make the relief measures a success.

    To those who have lost their jobs as a result of the fire, we have appealed to all shops and merchants throughout Singapore to contribute generously to the relief of the unemployed people who have suffered from the fire. I hope they will come forward to give employment to these victims so that they could rebuild their homes and live a good life again.

    Regarding the few points raised by the Member for Hong Lim, I wish to answer them now. The Member said that there were too many people housed in the centres, so that they were faced with many difficulties, such as sleeping accommodation and so on. I was at the relief centre day and night and looked after all their problems. We have built many camps to relieve the congestion in the crowded centres. In these camps there are beds for the use of the fire victims. The reason for the congestion

Column: 1580

at the Seng Poh School Centre is that about 1,000 victims were first accommodated there as a temporary measure.

    As to the complaint of shortage of food, I think there is no justification. After the fire the Government prepared a large amount of food to feed the hungry victims. There was enough food for distribution, but because of the great rush for it, the work of distribution was hampered. However, this has been rectified.

    As to the suggestion for more police to patrol the site and to assist the fire victims, I would say that Government has already adopted this measure in the past few days. The fire victims who could not manage to save their belongings during the fire were allowed to go back to the devastated site after the fire to salvage their belongings.

    These are the measures that the Government has taken after the disaster.

3.25 p.m.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, might I say how deeply moved we on the Opposition side are by the recent fire and all the calamity and disaster that it has brought to these 15,000 odd people? In this matter, Sir, we are entirely at one with the Government and other Members in this House who have just spoken.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I hope you will not think this is a matter which is out of keeping with the debate.
